statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Oregon State 88, Arizona State 66
article.story: CORVALLIS, Ore. (AP) -- Under a doctor's order to sit out the game while undergoing treatment for hypertension, Oregon State coach Jay John was never far from his team. John popped in the Beavers' locker room for a quick pre-game pep talk and then watched on a TV set in the Gill Coliseum basement as his team thrashed Arizona State 88-66 on Thursday night. Third-year assistant Kevin Mouton filled as coach, and the Beavers put together their best shooting night since 1999, hitting 62.5 percent of their shots. David Lucas scored 27 points and Nick DeWitz added 22 on 9-of-9 shooting for Oregon State (11-6, 3-3 Pacific-10 Conference). Ike Diogu had 27 points for Arizona State (13-4, 2-4). Kevin Kruger added nine points and eight assists for the Sun Devils, who have lost three straight conference games. Jason Fontenet had 12 points off the bench and Chris Stephens and J.S. Nash added 11 for the Beavers, who were coming off demoralizing losses to Washington, Washington State and Oregon. "We viewed this as a must-win," said Oregon State guard Lamar Hurd. "We felt like we were in a desperate situation. You can't lose at home and expect to finish in the first half in the conference." Diogu, the Pac-10 leader in scoring, rebounding and blocks entering the game, carried the load for the Sun Devils in the first half, scoring 22 of their first 32 points. His back-to-back 3-pointers gave Arizona State a 28-22 lead, but the Beavers' shooting kept them in the game. DeWitz made all five of his first-half shots and Fontenet hit all four of his as Oregon State took a 42-39 lead at the break. Oregon State dominated the second half as Diogu's influence evaporated. Defended by Lucas, he scored just five points and committed five of his eight turnovers after halftime. "Diogu was scoring easily early on and at that point I had to sit down and say 'what do we do to solve this,' " Mouton said. "We really picked it up on defense after that." Stephens' back-to-back baskets increased Oregon State's lead to 61-48. After an Arizona State timeout, Lucas powered inside for two points, Nash hit two free throws and Hurd fed DeWitz for an alley-oop dunk that made the lead 19 points. "We are not really taking pride in our defense," Diogu said. "It's not just one person, it's everybody." John was hospitalized this weekend in Seattle after leaving the Beavers' 108-68 loss to Washington at halftime with chest pains and shortness of breath. John said he feels better and that he will try to be back on the bench for Saturday's game against No.13 Arizona, but that decision will be made by doctors. DeWitz, a junior from Chandler, Ariz., who was recruited by Arizona State, put up his career-best scoring night. "I just took advantage of mismatches," he said. "Everything was falling for me." ^
